channel.title: News on JW Caterine
channel.description: Recent content in News on JW Caterine

item.title: Newspocalypse VA Podcast
item.description: I started a podcast this month where I interview journalists and media people about the challenges of the modern news industry and what they’re doing to get over the pitalls. My first episode features a former opinions editor who started a successful Substack newsletter after he got laid off, and my second features a journalist union leader who went on strike for better wages on Feb. 1. More to come!

item.title: Healthcare Shortfalls in Rural Virginia
item.description: My last article for Virginia Mercury before I started my new job at Virginia Sea Grant was months in the making. I traveled to the ODU mobile clinic in South Virginia and to the free health clinic in the Northern Neck as part of my investigation into the lack of healthcare in rural Virginia. Check out the walkthrough of the mobile clinic below!

item.title: Documentary on First Integrated Graduating Class in Williamsburg
item.description: The Local Black Histories Project put together a compelling film about the experiences of Black students who first integrated in the WJCC school system. There will be another screening at the Williamsburg Regional Library on Sunday, Nov. 19 at 2 PM.

item.title: New Roof for Jamestown Church Tower
item.description:
This story will be my last about Historic Jamestown for the foreseeable future, but I still plan on going back as a visitor, including to see the progress on this project!

Ribbon-cutting at Historic Jamestown to commemorate new roofing at the church tower, the only remaining 17th century above ground structure on site. pic.twitter.com/aRqFrCKB6v

— J Duh Yuh (@jwcat757) October 4, 2023

item.title: New Plan Aims to Reverse Declining Water Quality at Powhatan Creek
item.description: The James City County Board of Supervisors has approved an updated Powhatan Creek Watershed Management Plan, aiming to address environmental concerns in the region. Powhatan Creek, the county’s largest watershed, has seen some stream channels deteriorate, with 30% in poor or marginal conditions. Read my coverage here.

item.title: Life Sciences Innovation Center coming to downtown Richmond
item.description: Activation Capital is working to establish a life sciences innovation center in Richmond, Virginia, to support biotech startups by providing much-needed lab space. I wrote about the $53 million innovation center in the latest Virginia Business Magazine. The final space is projected to be 107,000 square feet and offer incubator and lab facilities for early-stage biotech companies.

item.title: Fire Chief Gives Play-by-play of Brushfire Response
item.description: A large brush fire in the Croaker area of James City County has been burning for weeks, presenting a unique challenge to the fire department due to its size and intensity. I reported on Fire Chief Ryan Ashe’s presentation to the Board of Supervisors on how his team responded.

item.title: New Chief Seeks Fresh Start for Troubled Department
item.description: A new report obtained by the Gazette showed that before Chief Mark Jamison took over the James City County Department, officers described it as a “toxic” agency and cited “racial tension” as a concern. I had the chance to interview the new chief and ask about his plans to correct the agency’s course.

item.title: Jamestown Archaelogists Discover Sword Fragments
item.description: Archaeologists at Historic Jamestowne found sword and dagger fragments, likely from three different weapons, in the “Governor’s Well.”

item.title: James City County Board of Supervisor Elections
item.description: This year, James City County voters will choose new members for the Board of Supervisors, with three out of five seats available. I published a rundown of the positions of incumbents John McGlennon and Ruth Larson as well as other candidates Trevor Topping, John Curran, Barbara Null, and Lisa Ownby.

item.title: School Bus Service Returns After Community Rallies
item.description: I’ve reported on when non-transportation zones were first announced for WJCC elementary school students, as well as the protests against it when school started a few weeks ago. I also had a chance to walk one of the routes myself from Longhill Grove to DJ Montague. I was happy to see this resolution for some students, but there are still more at Stonehouse, Norge and Laurel Lane elementary schools where this policy is still in place.

item.title: First Articles at Richmond Inno
item.description: My first two articles for Richmond Inno include a look at Charlottesville company Bonumose and their quest to develop scalable sugar alternatives as well as robotic school safety company Knightscope and their roadshow in Richmond.

item.title: Families Want Bus Service Back
item.description: The non-transportation zones means that students that live within a half mile of their school will no longer receive bus service. Back when this change was initially announced, I reported on parents who protested at a May school board meeting, but now more parents are finding out and are not happy about it. The next school board meeting should be interesting.

item.title: Easy Enrollment Off to Good Start
item.description: I’ve enjoyed covering healthcare stories for the Mercury, and the easy enrollment program is the latest subject I’ve reported on. The General Assembly passed a law in 2021 that puts a checkbox on state tax forms where filers can volunteer their information to get connected to resources from the Department of Medical Assistance Services. This coming tax year will be the first time that tax filers can check the same box to get connected to the state health benefits exchange which launches November 1.

item.title: Governor's Well Excavation
item.description: In my previous reporting on Historic Jamestown, I’ve mentioned past well excavations they’ve done, but it is exciting to be able to report on one happening in real time. The team there has been super welcoming and even let me climb into the excavation cribbing around the dig. Who knows what they’ll find?

item.title: VA Ed Policies Not Enforceable
item.description:
It does not appear that the state has anyway to force school boards to adopt the Virginia Department of Education’s model policies which make it more difficult for transgender students to go by their preferred identity at school, according to my reporting.

The Trevor Project’s 2022 National Survey on LGBTQ Youth Mental Health found that LGBTQ youth who said they had a LGBTQ-affirming school system reported lower rates of attempting suicide. A 2021 GLSEN survey of School Climate for LGBTQ+ Students in Virginia reported that only 40% of Virginian LGBTQ+ students said that their school administration was “somewhat or very supportive” of LGBTQ+ students.

I really admire the students and families who are organizing against these policies and led a mass walkout last year when they were first announced. You can support Pride Liberation Project here.

item.title: York County Hockey
item.description:
The owner of the Norfolk Admirals bought the Kiln Creek ice rink earlier this year, and last month the York County Board of Supervisors approved an agreement that will allow county residents access to open skating sessions twice a week and hockey classes once a month.

With purchase of York County rink, Admirals owner aims to build a bigger ice-sports community https://t.co/wOIVbnGKBc

— The Virginia Gazette (@vagazette) August 2, 2023

item.title: Virginia Business August Issue
item.description:
I have four stories in the August Issue of Virginia Business: one on Richmond’s repeal of minimum parking requirements, one on a couple of Virginia startup incubators competing for a SBA grant, one on a new tuition-assistance program at MBU, and one about the city of Bristol’s switch to a new destination marketing organization in Southwest Virginia.

This is the first time I’ve published my work in a magazine - happy to put another notch on my journalism belt! I’m currently working for other new publications as well. Stay tuned!

item.title: JCC Terminates School Contract
item.description: I spoke with a few different sources after James City County announced it would end its contract with the school division, and people were in shock. I will be covering the school board work session tomorrow, where the superintendent is expected to speak publicly for the first time on it. Will be interesting to see how this issue develops into the fall, when the City of Williamsburg plans to start its feasibility study on starting its own school division.

item.title: Construction on Richmond Rd
item.description:
Better sidewalks and new bike lanes are coming to the area around the Norge Shopping Center. I haven’t been to Norge in a minute. It was nice to visit and take some pictures.

Norge pic.twitter.com/IF3lLkapO2

— J Duh Yuh (@jwcat757) July 22, 2023

item.title: WJCC New Library Rule
item.description: The new policy takes away parents’ abilities to remove books for all children at a school like what happened earlier this year. It followed a memo by the state superintendent, but I’m curious if other localities will interpret it in the same way.

item.title: Eastern State Property Sale
item.description: Fun fact - I actually ran a cross-country meet in high school on the Eastern State Hospital campus. Now over 300 acres of that property is for sale, although the finalized timeline of when a deal will close is still up in the air. These parcels were determined to be in excess of what the hospital needed, although my other recent report on the shortage of state beds for psychiatric patients brings that assessment into question.

item.title: Grove
item.description: Grove is a beautiful neighborhood in south James City County with a rich history that unfortunately hasn’t always gotten the attention it deserves. While reporting for this story I had the chance to volunteer at the Grove rec center for a beginning of summer festival, and it was a pleasure getting to meet the residents.

item.title: First Coding Video Walkthrough
item.description: Today I published a story for Virginia Mercury about failures of the state’s psychiatric system, specifically not having enough beds to accomodate those in mental health crisis. I recorded a video walkthrough on how I was able to write some simple code in Python to extract, analyze, and visualize the data from a public records request that became the basis of this story.

item.title: Colonial Parkway Rehabilitation
item.description: It will be interesting to see how the entrance fee controversy with Colonial Parkway earlier this year plays out in the context of this bigger rehabilitation project as far as the community’s relationship with the National Park Service.

item.title: Driver's Ed Equity
item.description: I want to look at equity issues at WJCC schools beyond this story on driver’s education not being offered at Lafayette High School with the highest minority student population, but content to get started.

item.title: Juneteenth
item.description:
This year’s Juneteenth celebration in Williamsburg was super fun and educational. I hope next year it will be a bigger countywide event.

Some more moments from #Juneteenth celebration in #Williamsburg https://t.co/jSik50xydD pic.twitter.com/pfUkSEKcGR

— J Duh Yuh (@jwcat757) June 20, 2023

item.title: VIMS Science Day
item.description: My wife and I were visiting the Virginia Institute of Marine Science for their annual Science Day open house, and I realized I should probably write a story about it! It’s amazing all of the cool places I wasn’t aware of when I went to school in the area a decade ago. Definitely plan on going back!

item.title: Short-term Rental Twist
item.description: The Board of Supervisors approved a couple of Special Use Permits against the recommendation of the planning commission this past week. These are the first cases I’ve reported on from start to finish since I started doing journalism in Virginia. You can read my planning commission coverage here and the discussion at this month’s joint meeting to get the full story.

item.title: JCC to Join York Emergency Center
item.description: Published a story this week on the pending merger of the local emergency call center to now include James City County.

item.title: Solar Coming to WJCC Schools
item.description: This week I reported on Dominion Energy Solutions pitching solar roofs to WJCC schools. It brings me back to when I reported on solar power in Austin.

item.title: Short-term Rentals and Libraries
item.description: This week I had a few pieces come out in the Gazette, including my coverage of the JCC Board of Supervisors meeting. Two of the main topics of discussion were possible new regulations for short-term rentals as well as plans for new libraries.

item.title: USDA Funding for Food Banks Delayed
item.description: It’s still unclear why over $6 million in USDA funding for VA farmers and food banks took so long to be released. This was one of those stories that was developing as I was covering it which is always exciting if a little nerve-wracking.

item.title: Retired Poquoson Fire Chief Bio
item.description: I did an interview with retired Poquoson Fire Chief Robert Holloway. Growing up in Poquoson, it’s a milestone for me to do a story about the place where I lived for so many years.

item.title: WJCC School Board Coverage
item.description: I covered the school board in Austin for the Monitor, and now I’m covering the WJCC school board. The main points of comment at the latest meeting were the book removal at a couple of local high schools as well as the nontransportation zones which are expected to apply to elementary schools in the coming school year.

item.title: New Tours at Jamestown
item.description: I covered the new tours at Historic Jamestown. It is quickly becoming one of my favorite places to visit locally.

item.title: X-Glide Profile
item.description: I published my first piece in RVA Mag about young dancer X-Glide. As a dancer myself, I was grateful for the opportunity to give back to the Virginia dance scene as well as show off my photography more than my usual pieces.

item.title: James City County Budget
item.description: I’m excited to be covering more James City County Board Meetings and continuing to learn more about local politics. I also covered the following WJCC school board meeting where the division approved their budget as well, including a 7% raise for teachers.

item.title: Sidewalk Project
item.description: I covered a sidewalk project that has been several years in the making near Clara Byrd Baker Elementary School. I had been trying to get hold of the school’s principal for an interview without any luck, but when I went to the site to take photos I ended up running into him! Journalism 101.

item.title: Short-term Rentals
item.description:
I felt like I was back in Austin doing my housing beat when I attended the JCC Planning Commission Meeting this past week.

If city commission meetings were D&D games does that make staff the DM?

— J Duh Yuh (@jwcat757) May 3, 2023

item.title: Pedal the Parkway
item.description: I did a preview piece on Pedal the Parkway which is happening this weekend. Can’t speak for my readers but I know my wife and I were hesitant to go on the chance we could be charged the entrance fee. I also posted a video with Emil from the Bicycle Co-Op explaining how he fixes up old bikes:

item.title: Williamsburg Landing Arboretum
item.description: I attended the Williamsburg Landing Arboretum Arbor Day celebration a week ago. One of the great things about reporting is learning new vocabulary like “cultivar,” a plant variety produced by selective breeding. I also posted a video of Grounds lead Justin Drewery explaining how to properly plant a potted tree:

item.title: Study Your Arts Dance Event
item.description:
X-Glide, winner of the Study Your Arts event

I competed and reported on the Study Your Arts dance competition at this year’s Something in the Water festival in VA Beach. It was a blast to return to the dance scene where my artistic journey began and be able to give back by covering the event as a journalist. So much talent among the young dancers - I’m excited to see what happens next. I also published a video recap on my dancer Youtube profile:

item.title: Historic Jamestowne Volunteers
item.description: I had the chance to go behind the scenes at Historic Jamestowne and meet some of the volunteers who work in the conservation lab as well as interpreters at the fort site. As a teenager visiting Historic Jamestowne, I mostly remember the heat. Now as an adult who actually appreciates history, I found everything there fascinating. It is very much an active archaeological site with new digs happening all the time, and I plan to go back soon. I also uploaded some supplemental interviews I did to youtube:

item.title: Lawrenceville Correctional Center
item.description: I published my first article in the Virginia Mercury on the only privately run prison in Virginia, Lawrenceville Correctional Center. I obtained a series of memos from the Virginia Department of Corrections that showed GEO Group, the private operator, has had $4.3 million in contract breaches since 2018. I uploaded the memos to DocumentCloud along with the contract and other related documents.
